text: there's nothing like a new home and
five-year-old Wiley is quite proud of
his family's new house in western
Massachusetts he's a big fan of the
closet and he helped paint the walls but
there's one thing that Wiley really
likes about his new house I like that
it's why Lee's house came with two kinds
of solar panels on the roof one for
electricity and one for hot water his
duplex is one of 20 low to
moderate-income and energy-efficient
homes being constructed at this
development called wisdom way solar
village
I asked Ann Perkins who's directing
construction of the project for the
Franklin County Housing and
Redevelopment Authority about what makes
these homes so efficient that they're
almost off the grid they call them near
zero net energy homes zero net energy
home is one that actually uses energy
but then it also generates energy and it
nets to zero in terms of what's
generated and what's used we check out
Wiley's basement where a direct current
inverter keeps track of how much energy
the panel's are generating it's showing
today five kilowatts have been generated
and estimates how much carbon dioxide is
being saved by not using electricity
generated by fossil fuels these homes
are designed to save money to owners can
expect to pay twenty five hundred
dollars less each year for energy than
owners of conventional homes according
to the builders if the families who buy
these homes and live in them are
reasonably conservative in their energy
use they will not pay an electric bill
over the course of a year though the
homes have visible solar panels for
electricity and for hot water the real
energy savings are in the walls
I talked with Chris Farley one of the
developments architects about one of my
favorite subjects insulation we we have
a what is essentially a 12 inch thick
exterior wall there's a double stud a
double stud wall one stud wall for the
exterior one for the interior and since
we have two walls and there's no
connection between these we can fill
that with insulation we get a very tight
very well insulated wall the insulation
the builders will use to fill up the
walls is the same stuff I had installed
in my attic in addition to the extra
insulation when it comes to residential
construction it's air sealing air
sealing air sealing it's it's sealing
the envelope as tightly as possible we
actually just had some of this foam
sprayed along our rim joist in our house
and we've had some insulation put into
our attic actually the blown cellulose
insulation but you know am I ever going
to get my house which is basically we're
retrofitting is it's tightly sealed as
this is it worth it for us to kind of
tear out the walls and do this sort of
it what do you recommend a homeowner
it's not building a new house right well
I mean I think the answer to your
question is no it doesn't make sense to
to start tearing apart to your entire
house if it's already constructed to try
to make it tighter but anything you can
do to decrease that infiltration and
increase the insulation value the other
exterior walls is a good thing okay well
that all sounds great and clearly
they've sealed the envelope on these
homes but it gets cold in Western
Massachusetts
what about heating I wondered can't buy
a boiler in America or a furnace in

it just don't exist turns out the houses
are so well sealed and insulated that
they only require a small gas heater to

less than a quarter of the energy of
many conventional furnaces Wiley's mom

in such an energy-efficient home and
their last place sounded a bit like my

it's just so different yeah nice one of
the most interesting things about these
homes is that they're actually quite
affordable
depending on the size they would range
from two hundred and ten thousand
dollars to two hundred and forty
thousand dollars on the open market
but eleven of the units are subsidized
and reserved for low and medium income

people are being attracted to that low
